Founders / Founding Members: Wolverhampton Wanderers Football Club was founded in 1877 in Wolverhampton, England. The club was one of the founding members of the Football League in 1888 and has a long history in English football, known for its distinctive gold and black colours and passionate supporter base.
About the Club: Wolverhampton Wanderers Football Club, commonly known as Wolves, is a professional football club based in Wolverhampton, England, competing in the Premier League. Founded in 1877, the club played a significant role in the early development of organised football and was one of the original members of the Football League. Wolves enjoyed their most successful period in the 1950s and 1960s, winning multiple top-flight titles and domestic cups, and have a strong tradition of competitive participation in English football. In the modern era, the club has spent several seasons in the Premier League, establishing itself as a respected top-flight competitor. In November 2025, Rob Edwards was appointed head coach to lead the team after a managerial change during the 2025–26 Premier League season. Wolves have a large support base and play their home matches at Molineux Stadium.

Fun Facts: Wolves were one of the original 12 founding members of the Football League in 1888, making them a historic cornerstone of organised football in England.
The club won three English top-flight titles in the 1950s under legendary manager Stan Cullis, a period often considered the club’s greatest era.
Molineux Stadium, opened in 1889, is one of the oldest continuously used professional football grounds in England.
Wolves have won the FA Cup four times, with the most recent victory in 1960.
The club has competed in European competitions and contributed to early conceptual developments that led toward Europe’s premier club tournaments.
